review.title: Qualitative Order of Magnitude Energy-Flow-Based Failure Modes and Effects Analysis
review.abstract: This paper presents a structured power and energy-flow-based qualitative modelling approach that is applicable to a variety of system types including electrical and fluid flow. The modelling is split into two parts. Power flow is a global phenomenon and is therefore naturally represented and analysed by a network comprised of the relevant structural elements from the components of a system. The power flow analysis is a platform for higher-level behaviour prediction of energy related aspects using local component behaviour models to capture a state-based representation with a global time. The primary application is Failure Modes and Effects Analysis (FMEA) and a form of exaggeration reasoning is used, combined with an order of magnitude representation to derive the worst case failure modes. The novel aspects of the work are an order of magnitude(OM) qualitative network analyser to represent any power domain and topology, including multiple power sources, a feature that was not required for earlier specialised electrical versions of the approach. Secondly, the representation of generalised energy related behaviour as state-based local models is presented as a modelling strategy that can be more vivid and intuitive for a range of topologically complex applications than qualitative equation-based representations.The two-level modelling strategy allows the broad system behaviour coverage of qualitative simulation to be exploited for the FMEA task, while limiting the difficulties of qualitative ambiguity explanation that can arise from abstracted numerical models. We have used the method to support an automated FMEA system with examples of an aircraft fuel system and domestic a heating system discussed in this paper.

metadata.title: Qualitative Order of Magnitude Energy-Flow-Based Failure Modes and Effects Analysis

sections.text: The new aspects of the work are a qualitative network analyzer of the order of magnitude (OM) to represent any power range and any topology, including multiple power sources, a feature not required for earlier specialized electrical versions of the approach. Second, the representation of generalized energy-related behavior as state-based local models is presented as a modeling strategy that can be more descriptive and intuitive for a range of topologically complex applications than qualitative equation-based representations. The two-step modeling strategy enables the broad coverage of the system behavior of qualitative simulations for the FMEA task, while limiting the difficulties of qualitative ambiguities that can arise from abstracted numerical models.

sections.heading: 2. The Qualitative Power Network
sections.text: The power grid (system circuit) is represented by resistors R as a structural component.The simulation task is to derive the effort for each resistance and the flow through each resistor that represents a power source (force or flow) in the network.A linear network uses the generalized version of the Ohm law for effort, flow and resistance, E = F · R, and returns the current mapping in Table 1. The first line is qualitatively ambiguous because each flow does not cause any loss of force due to a zero resistance. Physically, it is not possible to have a force drop over a zero resistance, and therefore the flow is represented in the fourth line as t to indicate an impossible event.A power grid is considered as a diagram G (T = 1 node) containing the nodes T and edges A representing the circuit resistance. Each edge has a value A > R = a pair of resistors measured between two (T = 1 node) and the node (E).

sections.heading: 2.2 Network Reduction
sections.text: The OM representation is used for each of the resistance, strain and flow variables of a power grid. The goal is to derive flow and effort values throughout the circuit, and this is achieved by reducing the circuit to a single equivalent resistor, by assigning the flow value and expanding the network that allocates effort and flow values at each level of expansion. However, network reduction is performed by a series and parallel (SP) circuit simplification with an OM version of the qualitative start delta (Y) transformation for non-SP cases as a consequence. sections.heading: 2.4 Distinguished Node
sections.text: Force is measured between two nodes, and for simplicity's sake, it is common practice to identify a distinguishable node in a network and make measurements in relation to that node. This then allows the effort to be measured "on" a node with the implicit assumption that the second node is the distinguishable node. This is usually the case in electrical systems where the distinguishable node is called earth or earth and is a reference node for voltage measurement and is often defined as a negative supply pole in a single source system. Generally, we define the symbol Z as the distinguishable zero node for a network of any kind with specific instances, e.g. A to represent the "atmosphere" for liquid flow systems. Note that Z does not provide any further limit in the qualitative effort space; it provides a structural reference point in the resistive network.Identifying Z allows the definition of "absolute" in relation to this effort.

sections.text: The network solver calculates the power consumption (P = E · F) for a single source. For a linear resilient network, we can use a qualitative version of the principle of superimposition, in which more than one source is connected to a single network (in which a single system is schematically recorded, it can actually comprise many isolated networks at any time, possibly in different domains, although all components in the schematic appear connected to each other), each network is analyzed separately for each source by inhibiting all other force sources and adding up the results. For sources s1... sn, the qualitative flow through an edge is given by the value sns1 F (e) = max (Fs1 (e). Fsn (e)))). For error configurations, the ambiguous result is useful to point out to an engineer that a range of possible failure can occur.

sections.heading: 3. Local Component Models and OM Time
sections.text: The resilient network calculates the power consumption, P, but cannot model a component that stores energy, En, since En = P · T for the time T. Displacement and momentum are the two independent properties resulting from the incorporation of time into the model (Figure 1). Energy, displacement and momentum are basically local properties of components derived from the power variables and time. Representation of time follows the OM approach described in Section 2.1. For a time t3n and flow f3n, d3 (n + m) = f3nt3n defines a shift d such as quantity of substance and time. An FSM representation of the behavior of local components has been proven sufficient for abstract behaviors to perform the task of error analysis. Time is represented by state changes and is explicitly represented by state transitions that capture the qualitative integration of effort or flow variables. The state of the power supply is used to trigger changes (such as the cause of an external power outlet).

sections.heading: 4. Faults and Exaggeration Reasoning
sections.text: Exaggeration Argumentation (Weld, 1988b, 1990, 1988a) offers an alternative qualitative method of explaining the worst impacts without the need for a differentiated qualitative calculation. Therefore, this form of reasoning is appropriate if we do not have detailed system equations, or, as for the global power grid, reasoning on causality is not carried out. A secondary advantage for our purpose is that exaggerated reasoning often produces more precise explanations. However, the disadvantage is that qualitative deviations are guaranteed, whereas exaggerative reasoning can lead to wrong predictions. For the purpose of the FMEA, there are two reasons why exaggerated errors are a reasonable strategy: first, the worst deviation effects are required, which lead to error models in the extremes of behavior; second, the reasoning can lead to wrong predictions.

sections.heading: 5. Generating an FMEA
sections.text: An automated FMEA is typically based on a behavior simulation for many component failures and operating scenarios. The creation of the FMEA has already been described in detail elsewhere (Price, 1998), but since it is the end goal of the modeling and simulation effort, we summarize the most important steps as follows: • The system is simulated without faulty components over the expected operating conditions. • The output of the simulation is the qualitative value of all system variables for each step (state) of the simulation. These are used by a completely separate function model that identifies specific (output) behavior with the state of the system functions identified. Functions can be presented in one of four states (Achieved, Failed, Unexpected Behaviour, Inoperative).

sections.heading: 7. Case Study Example: Aircraft Fuel System
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusions
sections.text: Qualitative simulation is a powerful modeling concept that can support a wide range of reasoning tasks. A number of tools for analyzing electrical circuits have been based on this approach, and the authors "electrical qualitative simulator, known as mcirq, is now in regular industrial use. Structural and behavioral models are composed and do not encode functional system information or make assumptions about their use. It is of course necessary to decide on the range and phenomena to be included in the modeling, and so a library of models is typically created for a specific area of application (e.g. automotive electrics, aircraft fuel system, general plumbing systems, general plumbing systems, etc.), and this includes the set of qualitative variables of interest, their (appropriately labeled) orders of magnitude and relevant component failure modes. The models are then reusable components that are less available to other systems available for use within the component, making it more complex.

referenceMentions.context: The OM representation is derived from a many valued resistance representation (Lee, 2000b) and although the many valued concept and its modelling and reasoning benefits are completely applicable to the OM representation, the actual technique for solving the circuits in that work was based on path labelling (Lee, 1999), and was not a general solution applicable to any network topology.

The OM representation is derived from a many valued resistance representation (Lee, 2000b) and although the many valued concept and its modelling and reasoning benefits are completely applicable to the OM representation, the actual technique for solving the circuits in that work was based on path labelling (Lee, 1999), and was not a general solution applicable to any network topology.

Previous work by the authors (Snooke, 2007) on the modelling of fluid flow systems was based on an electrical network analyser (Lee, 1999) but could only deal with series parallel reducible circuits, and this becomes a limitation for topologically complex systems.

This representation is an improvement on a more restricted predecessor used for electrical component behaviour (Snooke, 1999), which was the foundation for a variety of automated electrical design analysis techniques.

Section 4 considers the use of the OM representation to perform exaggeration reasoning for failure analysis and section 5 provides a brief overview of the strategy (Price, 1998; Lee, Bell, & Coghill, 2001) used to process multiple simulation results into an FMEA output.

Previous work by the authors (Snooke, 2007) on the modelling of fluid flow systems was based on an electrical network analyser (Lee, 1999) but could only deal with series parallel reducible circuits, and this becomes a limitation for topologically complex systems. The incorporation of equivalent resistance reduction using star–delta (Y-∆) transforms (Mauss & Neumann, 1996) into the OM representation (Section 2.2) allows effort and flow variables for resistive networks of any topology to be solved by reduction and flow assignment expansion (Section 2.3), and completes the work started by Lee. Complex network topologies are due in part to the need to represent concepts such as the ‘atmosphere’ in fluid flow systems, to allow failure modes such as leaks in closed systems, as well as vented elements in other systems. This unique ‘zero’ node is common to several domains and is generalised in the present work in Section 2.4. Applying the techniques derived by Lee (1999) to non electrical systems reveals two limitations.

Power flow is a global phenomenon where cause and effect is undetermined and can be very efficiently analysed as a network, avoiding problems of causal instability and ambiguity arising from systems of equations generated from interacting components with local behaviours (Skorstad, 1992a).

Qualitative versions of bond graphs can be produced (Ghiaus, 1999), however these are qualitative versions of the standard numerical equations and therefore suffer the same difficulties as any of the general equation-based constraint methods.
The most widely-used qualitative equation-based constraint method has been QSIM (Kuipers, 1986).

This does not limit the applicability because it is the property of the model that is discrete or continuous rather than any inherent property of the system (Struss, 2003), and the real question is what kind of model is appropriate for the reasoning task at hand.

Bond graphs share the same underlying energy-flow-based concept as the lower level of our approach, and are a popular domain-independent graphical method for describing a system first described by Paynter (1961) and developed by numerous others.
A minimal useful qualitative quantity space uses [0, r,∞] to represent resistance and [0,u] to represent effort, E , at the supply terminals (Lee, 1999).

1 Order of Magnitude Representation An order of magnitude representation for R allows more detailed modelling without introducing qualitative ambiguity by separating artefacts with significantly different characteristics (Raiman, 1991; Lee, 2000a).

1 Order of Magnitude Representation An order of magnitude representation for R allows more detailed modelling without introducing qualitative ambiguity by separating artefacts with significantly different characteristics (Raiman, 1991; Lee, 2000a).

The introduction of Y-∆ resistances unfortunately reduces the vividness of the representation since they are not directly related to the original component structure; however, it provides a general solution and can assign flow direction for any network, unlike earlier work (Lee, 2000a).
The qualitative effort levels [0, u] are supplemented – as for voltage (Lee, 1999) – with two additional symbols that represent structural features of the circuit that emerge during simulation.

Sophisticated techniques have been added to the Bond graph methodology (Brown, 2010), which allow numerical models of thermofluidic phenomena to be constructed; however, the complexity required of these models is such that the benefits of the broad-based qualitative modelling for system engineering analysis such as FMEA is lost.

Some alternative approaches to qualitative reasoning have considered changes of material state for example a ‘plug-based’ ontology (Skorstad, 1992b) which is able to model the phase transitions in a steam boiler tube, however, the modelling required is necessarily detailed and the 13 state envisionment produced illustrates the complexity of the phenomena.

Another approach to avoid complexity is used by Ghiaus who provides a qualitative model for the Carnot refrigeration cycle (Ghiaus, 1999) based on equations derived from a thermal bond graph and thus does not include substance properties as the system is assumed to be in equilibrium, precluding analysis of many failure modes.

There are, however, several additional concepts (Lee, 1999; Lee et al., 2001) that remain applicable using the SPS technique, and can provide additional vividness in the representation as well as computational benefit.

There are, however, several additional concepts (Lee, 1999; Lee et al., 2001) that remain applicable using the SPS technique, and can provide additional vividness in the representation as well as computational benefit.
To avoid such difficulties a simplified numerical model containing the relevant behavioural phenomena, can be used (Dressler et al., 1993) and subsequently refined this into a qualitative one.

Producing the FMEA has been previously described in detail elsewhere (Price, 1998), however, since it is the end goal of the modelling and simulation effort, we summarise the main steps as follows: • The system is simulated with no failed components over the expected operating conditions.
The textual descriptions are derived from the functional model (Bell et al., 2007; Price, 1998) and provide an easily understood explanation of the fault effects and risk priority.
The textual descriptions are derived from the functional model (Bell et al., 2007; Price, 1998) and provide an easily understood explanation of the fault effects and risk priority.
The consistency of the fully automated FMEA analysis allows other automated tasks to be performed such as a diagnosability analysis (Snooke, 2009; Snooke & Price, 2012).

The qualitative simulation has also been used to generate sets of symptoms that relate qualitative measurements, symptoms and failures (Snooke, 2009) in order to allow a diagnosability analysis to be performed with the aim of assisting sensor selection.
approach in related work (Rosich, 2012; Krysander & Frisk, 2008).

metadata.abstractText: This paper presents a structured power and energy-flow-based qualitative modelling approach that is applicable to a variety of system types including electrical and fluid flow. The modelling is split into two parts. Power flow is a global phenomenon and is therefore naturally represented and analysed by a network comprised of the relevant structural elements from the components of a system. The power flow analysis is a platform for higher-level behaviour prediction of energy related aspects using local component behaviour models to capture a state-based representation with a global time. The primary application is Failure Modes and Effects Analysis (FMEA) and a form of exaggeration reasoning is used, combined with an order of magnitude representation to derive the worst case failure modes. The novel aspects of the work are an order of magnitude(OM) qualitative network analyser to represent any power domain and topology, including multiple power sources, a feature that was not required for earlier specialised electrical versions of the approach. Secondly, the representation of generalised energy related behaviour as state-based local models is presented as a modelling strategy that can be more vivid and intuitive for a range of topologically complex applications than qualitative equation-based representations. The two-level modelling strategy allows the broad system behaviour coverage of qualitative simulation to be exploited for the FMEA task, while limiting the difficulties of qualitative ambiguity explanation that can arise from abstracted numerical models. We have used the method to support an automated FMEA system with examples of an aircraft fuel system and domestic a heating system discussed in this paper.
